text: In an exclusive investigation for reported.ly, journalist Nina Bigalke traveled to an oil concession deep in the Amazon rainforest to film an illegal access road, the existence of which Ecuador's government has denied. As indigenous peoples seek to secure the future of their ancestral lands, President Rafael Correa faces fierce political opposition ahead of a huge expansion of oil production into Ecuador's Yasuní National Park.
By Nina Bigalke
"I'm sure, I'm positive that there is no road," Yvonne Fabara, Ecuador's hydrocarbons secretary, replied when I asked her about the operations of a state-owned oil company in the Amazon rainforest.

She was referring to a particularly remote and fragile area of Yasuní National Park near the border with Peru. With more than 100,000 species per hectare, the UNESCO biosphere reserve is one of the most biodiverse places on the planet. It is home to several indigenous peoples, including two tribes who live in voluntary isolation. Yasuní also holds an estimated 20% of Ecuador's oil deposits, a resource that accounts for nearly half of Ecuador's exports.

Oil drilling in this part of the rainforest, called Block 31, was authorized on condition that no roads be built there. But satellite images published in a 2014 report revealed what appeared to be a road cutting some 20km into the protected area. Using these images, geographers from the University of Padua in Italy and a researcher from the Amazon Conservation Association calculated the road as being 26 meters wide.

Despite the satellite imagery evidence from the report, Ecuador's government maintains that the oil company in charge, state-owned Petroamazonas, built only a temporary "ecological trail" in order to bury a flowline, in compliance with the environmental license for the oil block. The only way to know for sure would be to travel through this remote corner of the Amazon and visit Block 31 in person.
Armed guards and military prevented environmental campaigners, the YASunidos, from entering Block 31 in 2014 (Photo: Yasunidos)

Assurances by Secretary Fabara that the methods employed by PetroAmazonas in the sensitive area are "being monitored by everybody" were rebutted by Professor Massimo De Marchi, an expert in sustainable development and environmental science and one of the authors of the 2014 report. De Marchi said that independent on-the-ground checks in Yasuní are almost impossible due to the remoteness of the forest and the "typical military and private security activities" that surround oil operations.
"The problem is a lack of transparency," De Marchi said, explaining that myriad incompatible claims have intensified what is now a political controversy.

Recent letters obtained by reported.ly outline how Ecuador's environment ministry refused two observation groups permission to visit the oil production facility in 2015, in one case citing environmental concerns.

In late 2014, Ecuador's government banned a delegation of German MPs from visiting the country when it was discovered the MPs planned to visit Yasuní National Park and meet with people opposed to the drilling. Meanwhile, a group of young environmentalists called YASunidos were confronted by armed guards and military as they tried to reach the area earlier that year.
Since no one else had been allowed to inspect the site, I decided to try and see the "trail" for myself.
A heavy truck passes along the oil access road deep in Yasuni National Park (Nina Bigalke)

Reaching the disputed location took me on a journey deep into the forest by boat and canoe along the Napo and Tiputini rivers. Inside Yasuní, residents from local Kichwa communities helped me to navigate the pristine wilderness and cross into Block 31, one of the latest oil concessions to be drilled. They do not want to be named for fear of reprisal.

For days, all we passed in our canoe was an abundance of animals and dense canopies. As we neared the disputed location, suddenly a stretch of road rose from the banks of the river. To avoid being met by armed security, we continued past and doubled-back on foot, making our way through the forest with a machete. Our slow progress through thick undergrowth brought home the sharp contrast, when out of nowhere a massive clearing opened in front of us.

Within minutes, vehicles approached. The rumble of a heavy truck drowned out the ubiquitous chirping of rainforest insects and birds. Soon after, a smaller truck approached. Both passed by, moving further along what was clearly a road.

In the Amazon, roads are known to impact the habitat well beyond their boundary. Various studies, including a January 2010 research paper published in the peer-reviewed journal PLOS One, have shown that oil access roads built in other parts of Yasuní and its surrounding buffer zone "have facilitated colonization, deforestation, fragmentation, and overhunting of large fauna ... and illegal logging."

"You typically end up losing at least all the large fauna like tapirs and peccaries and the large species of birds within a very short period of time," says Dr. Kelly Swing, an expert in environmental science and director of the Tiputini Biodiversity Station, a research facility inside Yasuní.

To preserve the rainforest, the 2007 environmental licence for Block 31 stipulated a roadless design, where the oil platform – "essentially an island in the forest" – is serviced by a fleet of boats and helicopters, much like an offshore platform. To get the crude oil to a processing facility, the roadless access is combined with an underground flowline. This requires a temporary trail to bury the flowline before restoring the original geography.
This method is significantly more costly than building a traditional access road, but widely considered best practice in sensitive environments.
"There is no need to have a highway there," Secretary Fabara confirmed when we spoke in late 2014, before I visited Block 31. "Absolutely no need."

The 2007 environmental license allowed the "ecological trail" to have a maximum width of 4.5 meters and a total clearing of no more than 10 meters tree-to-tree. Petroamazonas inherited the agreement when it took over the drilling concession from Brazilian oil company Petrobras in 2009. In 2011, Petroamazonas was permitted to increase the clearance width to a maximum of 14 meters.

The widest point of the clearing I filmed was about 30 meters, more than twice as wide as specified in the amended license and about three times as wide as in the 2007 license. Satellite images show segments of the road where the clearing is much wider.
The oil access road filmed by Nina Bigalke in Ecuador's Amazon rainforest .
"Once [the flowline] is buried, you don't have to have anything on the surface", Secretary Fabara said when we spoke in Quito. "You just rebuild whatever damage you did and it just evaporates."
None of the experts interviewed by reported.ly know of an oil access road in Yasuní that "evaporated" or that was later revegetated with natural habitat.

"Yes, if we wait 100 years, we can have a forest, maybe," Professor De Marchi, co-author of the University of Padua report, said. "But the problem is, it's a big investment. So, where you have a road, you improve the road, you open new roads. It's absurd to close a road. When you open the first cut, it's impossible to come back."
One of several bridges built to cross rivers inside Yasuni (GeoYasuni.org)

Furthermore, the morphology of the clearing has fundamentally changed and differs vastly from the pictures of a benign trail in official literature. The video clearly shows that construction materials alien to the jungle, such as compacted gravel, were introduced to build the road surface. Trenches were dug and satellite images show permanent "water-crossing structures" along the road.

"They had to cut the top of the hill to have less of a slope for vehicles," Dr. Francesco Ferrarese, geographical expert at the University of Padua, observed when he saw the video. "I think this is extremely interesting, because it is difficult to restore the original morphology."

In the politically charged battle over the right to define the future of an ever-shrinking territory of pristine rainforest, the road in Block 31 is significant, not least because of its strategic location. It lies directly adjacent to the last untouched oil block of Yasuní that until recently had been off-limits for oil operations: Block 43, often referred to by the acronym ITT, short for the Ishpingo, Tiputini and Tambococha oil fields within its boundary.

In August 2013, President Rafael Correa abandoned a high-profile initiative to keep the oil in the soil, paving the way for a major expansion of drilling into the ITT oil fields. In April 2014, Correa's government rejected two thirds of 756,000 signatures collected by the YASunidos environmentalists to force a public referendum on the issue. Permits allowing Petroamazonas to drill were signed a month later. Set to begin in 2016, Petroamazonas has been granted the new drilling license.
As with Block 31, the expansion into ITT came with promises to use "cutting-edge technology" to mitigate any impacts.

A conference of petroleum engineers in Quito in 2014 foreshadowed "the possibility of extending [existing] roads" into ITT, according to Bill Powers, chief engineer with a USA-based consultancy, in an interview by the Guardian.

Roads have been built into Block 16 and Block 31. ITT is the next concession slated for oil production. The fear is that road connections will be built through these blocks (Credit: InfoAmazonia.org/GeoYasuni.org)

Presenting at the conference, a representative of Ecuadorian oil services company SERTECPET mooted opening road access to ITT through neighboring Block 31, Powers said. A Petroamazonas representative who spoke at the conference "was quite honest and straightforward about the fact it was cheaper to put in a road than to rely on helicopters" and that "they had the intention of applying the same development philosophy in ITT," he said.
A government official at that conference, Minister for Strategic Sectors Rafael Poveda, made familiar assurances that "the transport of materials will be done by helicopter and by river."

The issue has hit a nerve in Ecuador, not least because the OPEC member state depends heavily on crude exports. Oil resources are state-owned in Ecuador and, subject to market fluctuations, generate about half of all export revenues.

Since the country defaulted on its debt in 2008, it has come to rely heavily on Chinese loans linked to guaranteed oil exports and projects involving Chinese companies. Further such deals have been struck as Ecuador's government looks to China and elsewhere to mitigate the impact of plummeting crude prices on the country's economy.

Quito. August 27, 2013: A riot policeman holds a shield reading "Life" (written by protestors) during clashes following a protest against the exploitation of oil in the Yasuni National Park (JUAN CEVALLOS/AFP/Getty Images)

Profits from record crude prices in the past had been ploughed into public spending on infrastructure, health and education, but four decades of oil operations have left people divided over the ills and benefits of the industry.
For the local population in the affected areas, the impacts are impossible to ignore. Oil spills are amongst the most visible ones.

More than two decades into a class action lawsuit against Texaco / Chevron, little has been done to clean up the toxic sludge and crude oil left behind in leaking open-air waste pits in a formerly pristine forest to the north of Yasuní. An Amazon Watch / Vice News expose alleged that Chevron tried to cover up the resulting environmental damage by deliberately seeking uncontaminated soil samples. Chevron public affairs officer Morgan Crinklaw disagreed, saying the sampling work was not conducted improperly.
Above: The Chevron Tapes
More recently, thousands of barrels of crude spilled into the Aguarico river after a Petroamazonas pipeline ruptured in July 2014.

Although "spills are the events that make their way into the public conscience," environmental scientist Dr. Swing stresses that in terms of environmental impacts, "oil companies do many things even before they get to the point of extracting oil."

"Any oil operation involves thousands of workers. We are talking about developing small towns in different parts of the forests. We usually think of that as a minor aspect, but those are impacts that go on day after day after day for years, having a chronic effect on the environment."

Such drastic changes continue to affect indigenous communities, some of who choose to live in voluntary isolation in the remaining untouched parts of the forest. Many have been fighting oil operations on their ancestral lands for years.
"The people that we are opposing, they tell us, 'If you continue, you will be persecuted,'" a resident of Yasuní tells me.

"This fight is not for myself or my parents or grandparents, it is for our children, and our children's children, so they do not have to live in a contaminated environment," he continued. "Otherwise, what are they supposed to say to them? That they are suffering because of the deeds of their parents?"

Above: A campaign by I Am Yasuni to create awareness of oil drilling in indigenous Amazon lands. The group was initially funded by Ecuador's government "to help get funding to save the Yasuní," an organiser told reported.ly. "When our efforts turned out to be successful, we were shut down and the government broke all communication with us."

President Correa has taken contradictory measures through his quasi-authoritarian leadership. He shelters WikiLeaks founder Julian Assange in Ecuador's London Embassy while curbing press freedoms at home. In 2008, he initiated the first constitution to put the "rights of nature" on a similar legal standing as human rights. A crackdown on NGOs in later years involved shutting down Pachamama, an organisation advocating those very rights, after it publicly opposed the expansion of oil drilling in the Amazon.

The environmental struggle has been exacerbated by what the independent watchdog Freedom House identified as a "pattern of cracking down on [...] critical voices" and a "downward trend" in freedom of expression.

Leaked internal documents of Ecuador's intelligence agency, the Secretaría Nacional de Inteligencia, indicate that "spies were targeting political groups and individuals seeking to conserve the forest," the Guardian's environment editor, John Vidal wrote. And Correa spent millions of Ecuador's intelligence budget "to delete content critical of him and the first lady," Buzzfeed reported.

As a direct result of the government's strong-arm rhetoric against environmentalists, "the environmental justice struggle is now completely linked with democracy," says Ivonne Yanez, director of the NGO Accion Ecologica. "This government accuses indigenous leaders of being terrorists and criminalizes young people for protesting against its environmental policies."

Demonstrators struggle with riot police during a march to protest against the policies of President Rafael Correa they say will result in more mining in the Amazon region and threaten the environment and their way of life, on March 22, 2012. Protests were prompted partly by a recent agreement between Ecuador and China for industrial copper mining in the Amazon's Ecuacorriente Zamora-Chinchipe region. The march was organized by the Confederation of Indigenous Nationalities of Ecuador (CONAIE), a powerful umbrella group that represents natives from around the country. Correa accused CONAIE of trying to destabilize his government. (RODRIGO BUENDIA/AFP/Getty Images)

The precise methods of production Petroamazonas will employ in the ITT oil fields remain to be seen. Valid concerns arise given the misleading narrative around production in Block 31 and the rebuttal of evidence that the environmental license was breached.

Contacted by email about evidence of a road in Block 31, Hydrocarbons Secretary Fabara replied that she was "most [concerned about] the information regarding Petroamazonas and the ITT as this is not within the scope of work."

Fabara said she spoke to Oswaldo Madrid, General Manager of Petroamazonas, who was copied into an email. Reported.ly invited Oswaldo Madrid to answer questions about the existence of the road, the timeframe and budget for restoring the original habitat, and plans for Block 43/ITT. These questions were also sent to Ecuador's Ministry of Environment and Ministry of Non-Renewable Natural Resources. We have not received replies to these questions at the time of publication.
Additional reporting by Malachy Browne.
Translations by Wendy Carrillo.
Edited by Malachy Browne.

Nina Bigalke is a solo video and broadcast journalist. She has freelanced for BBC World, Al Jazeera English, Channel 4 News, worked as a trainee TV reporter for ARD German TV and published work on the website of The Guardian. She holds a PhD from the London School of Economics. And currently works for AP Television News. Follow her on Twitter @NinaBigalke.

text: The Russian Federation Council authorized military deployment in Syria. Russian deployment was requested by Syrian president Assad, and will focus on airstrikes, as the Kremlin ruled out ground operations. French TF1 filmed Russian planes in Lattakia, delivered last week.
Syrian opposition groups claim they were targeted by Russian air strikes.
Meanwhile, a French prosecutor has opened an investigation over possible crimes against humanity committed by the Syrian president.

The only woman on Georgia's death row was executed. Kelly Gissendaner, who was convicted of killing her husband with the help of another man in 1997, lost her final round of appeals in the hours leading up to her execution in Georgia. Her children and Pope Francis asked for clemency but were denied.

The US carried out more airstrikes in Kunduz, Afghanistan, as NATO troops joined Afghan forces in the counteroffensive to retake the city from the Taliban. The Taliban shadow governor in the city was reportedly killed by airstrikes, but the ground push failed, while the Taliban managed to surround the airport.

#CARcrisis: Bangui, the capital of Central African Republic, had a quiet night after heavy clashes on Tuesday. Protests intended as peaceful were under way on Wednesday morning. Interim president Catherine Samba-Panza returned early from the UN General Assembly.
Amnesty International documented abuses by armed groups in CAR's diamond sector that may make blood diamond trade possible, in a new report that is being disputed by the Antwerp World Diamond Centre.

#EUmigrants: The migrants' camp in Ventimiglia, on the Italian-French border, was forcibly dispersed by the Italian police. Migrants had been sleeping there for months and have now moved back to the rocks facing the sea. They are still protesting for being blocked from entering France.

In Calais, an Eritrean man in his 20s died on Wednesday trying to cross the tunnel, run over by a freight train. He is the 13th person to be killed in the tunnel since June, as well as the second in two days.

Israeli jets launched four airstrikes on Gaza after a rocket fired at Ashdod by an ISIS affiliate was intercepted. There were no reports of casualties on either side. Suicides in the besieged strip are reported to be mounting.
Edward Snowden has joined Twitter. Within less than a day, he was followed by 905,000 people. As for now, he's only following one Twitter account – the NSA.
An estimated 5,248 people have died in the Yemen conflict. UNOCHA reported that Taiz was seeing increased fighting and has been without water since August.

A band of presidential guards in Burkina Faso refused to lay down their arms, resulting in an assault by the army in Ouagadougou. At the same time as gunfire was being exchanged, former coup leader Gilbert Diendere was on the radio describing them as "uncontrolled elements," and demanding they lay down their arms. The guard was stormed and the assault was over in a few hours.

Freddie Gray death trial delay: the first police officer, William Porter, will appear in court on Nov. 30, while trials for the other police officers will be held in January, February and March. Lawyer J. Wyndal explains why.
Japan only accepted 11 of about 5,000 asylum seekers in 2014. On Tuesday night, Prime Minister Abe said the country must raise the birth rate before accepting refugees.

Cuba's President Raul Castro and U.S. President Barack Obama met briefly Tuesday at a bilateral meeting on the 70th anniversary of the United Nations General Assembly.  This marked the first time a U.S. president met with a Cuban leader on American soil since the start of Cuba's revolution.

Thousands of people protested in the Republic of the Congo against President Daniel Sassou Nguesso's bid for a third term. Sassou Nguesso has ruled the republic for more than 30 years and recently announced a referendum to change laws allowing him to serve, although he is over the legal age.
Sixteen Turkish citizens who were kidnapped from a construction site in Iraq about a month ago were released on Wednesday in Basra, officials from both governments confirmed.

text: The Afghan army, supported by a US airstrike, launched an offensive to retake Kunduz after Taliban fighters seized control of the country's fifth largest city. In the first major attack on Kunduz since 2001, fighters took the provincial governor's office and set fire to buildings, including a UN compound. MSF reported several killings and serious injuries.

#CARcrisis: Violence has returned to Bangui where at least 30 people have been killed since Saturday. Protesters are demanding the resignation of the interim president, and MINUSCA peacekeepers are accused of opening fire on protesters. The UN says 27,000 people are displaced already. Hundreds of prisoners escaped from Bangui's only functioning prison.

The "accidental" airstrike of Saudi-led forces on a wedding in Yemen on Monday has reached a death toll of more than 130, making it one of the deadliest since airstrikes began in March. The update comes from the hospital in Maqbana, where the injured were taken. With Saudi forces denying responsibility, the UN condemned the attack.

Almost 100 people have died or went missing between Greece and Turkey in the last 10 days, in six different shipwrecks. HRW demanded that the EU consider safe routes for refugees. Weather has considerably worsened recently, but boats continue to arrive by the dozens in Greek islands.
MSF continues to rescue people at sea, despite the departure of MOAS' Phoenix for south-east Asia. The Dignity I rescued hundreds of people in recent days.

#EUMigrants: Croatia said that 82,000 refugees and migrants have entered the country since the crisis began. Hungary warned that it may close the border with Croatia, as nearly 25,000 crossed over the weekend.
It looks like Germany is using faster processing not only for refugee reception, but also for faster rejection of economic migrants:
Migrant or refugee? We're all people. Words Matter.

Amid rumors of the king's declining health, former Thailand PM Yingluck Shinawatra, who was ousted a few days before the military coup and stands charged of corruption, hit back at her opponents Tuesday with her own lawsuit. Meanwhile, worries grow around the military junta's plan to build a single national Internet gateway to monitor the web and block content.
Last Sunday, Thailand's army arrested veteran journalist and junta critic Pravit Rojanapruk for allegedly posting information online that "disturbed peace and order" in the country.

Four Britons were placed on the UN's sanctions list for membership of Islamic State. The two men and two women are accused of trying to recruit westerners to the terrorist group through social networks, among other charges.
Flights to Taipei have begun to return after Typhoon Dujuan swept past Taiwan. High winds and heavy rain swept the island. Playlist curated by YouTube Newswire.
The supermoon caused a supertide in parts of the UK, Miami and other places.
Finally, something to warm the cockles. School kids perform in Zimbabwe.

text: 'Umbrella Revolution' supporters peacefully marked the first anniversary of their movement in Hong Kong. Movement leaders gave speeches, and the crowd attempted to occupy Harcourt Road, but a heavy police presence was unyielding. A repeat of the teargassing a year ago was averted, and tension dissipated. Interviewed by Al Jazeera, Scholarism leader Joshua Wong said: "We hoped to get universal suffrage and direct elections and we failed," but focused on the long view.

Taliban fighters have reportedly seized control of half of Kunduz in the first major attack on the city since 2001. At least 8 people have been killed and 17 wounded. Local sources report that Taliban prisoners were freed. Fighting for Kunduz airport is ongoing at the time of writing.

Catalan separatist parties won just under a combined 50% in elections, with over 75% turnout, the highest since the return of democracy in Spain. Nationalist coalition Junts Pel Si won 62 seats, and leftists CUP 10 seats, but their alliance is not a given.

Seventeen Syrians drowned off the Turkish coast and 20 others were rescued by the Turkish Coast Guard. Five children were among the casualties. Some 20,000 people rallied in Brussels in support of refugees. A #refugeeswelcome rally was also held in Berlin.
Humans of New York creator Brandon Stanton is sharing refugee stories from the Greek islands.
Shell announced that they're stopping arctic drilling, after having spent $7 billion, citing disappointing results at their exploratory well.
An 8-year-old girl was killed in her house in Diyarbakir's Bismil district, in southeast Turkey. Conflicting reports attribute the killing to either PKK forces or police.

India launched a space observatory and six satellites in a single day. Astrosat is a smaller version of the Hubble Space Telescope, and its operational lifespan is expected at five years. Last week, India's Mars orbiter celebrated its first anniversary with the release of a Mars Atlas.
Our Wendy Carrillo is on assignment in Mexico City for the one-year anniversary of the disappearance of the 43 student-teachers from Ayotzinapa.
And a little announcement: The Online News Association recognised reported.ly in its annual awards for our coverage across distributed platforms of the Charlie Hebdo shootings in France.

text: Wendy Carrillo is on assignment in Mexico City for the one-year anniversary of the disappearance of the 43 student-teachers from Ayotzinapa.

Saturday, Sept. 26 was the one-year anniversary since 43 students of Ayotzinapa Rural Teachers' College went missing. To mark the date, parents of the missing students along with thousands of supporters descended onto Mexico City, the nation's capital.

The march began at the National Auditorium at noon, made its way down Reforma Ave, passing the Angel of Independence and ended at the Zocalo square several hours later. Despite rain, thousands of supporters from all over the country marched shouting, "Ayotzinapa Vive!" "Ayotzina Lives!" "Vivos se los llevaron y vivos los queremos!" "They took them alive, and we want them alive!"

On Thursday, Sept. 24, parents of the missing students met with President Enrique Peña Nieto and made eight demands which include international oversight to the Ayotzinapa investigation. The president has said he will do all he can to create an investigative unit with the Attorney General's office dedicated to finding people who have disappeared. The parents believe he's rhetoric are just empty promises.

Felipe de la Cruz, who is the uncle of one of the missing students and acting spokesperson for the parents, passionately told the crowd, "This is not a march to commemorate the one year anniversary, this is a march for justice! We want our sons back alive!"

The case has been an international embarrassment to the country and to the presidency of Peña Nieto. Various human rights groups, like Amnesty International Mexico have condemned the mismanagement of the case as well as the continued disappearances of Mexican people.
Wifi access has been limited, below are tweets from the march that help shed light to the momentous event and the impact it has had on the people of Mexico.
On Sunday, Sept. 27, the parents will hold another march in their home state of Guerrero.
title: Ayotzinapa: One year later, a march for justice

text: Wendy Carrillo is on assignment in Mexico City for the one-year anniversary of the disappearance of the 43 student-teachers from Ayotzinapa.

I arrived late Thursday afternoon to Mexico City and immediately made my way to the historic Zocalo square. There, amid the square's looming Mexican flag and the immensity of the gothic Metropolitan Cathedral – whose bells ringing every 30-minutes seem to announce the importance of the events – parents of the missing Ayotzinapa students are continuing their 43-hour hunger strike.

Saturday Sept. 26, will mark the one-year anniversary of the day when 43 student teachers from the Raúl Isidro Burgos Rural Teachers' College (better known as the Ayotzinapa Rural Teachers' College) went missing. After year-long protests and violence, there are still few answers. #Ayotzinapa has become a world-wide call to action on social media, shedding light on continued human rights violations in Mexico.

On Thursday afternoon, parents and key supporters met in a closed-door meeting with President Enrique Peña Nieto. He was late, and while the group was supposed to meet at Los Pinos, the residency of the President, the meeting was moved to a nearby museum. It is only the second meeting that the parents have had with the leader of the country since the students disappeared. Earlier this year, government officials released their findings of the investigation and declared the students were captured, killed and their bodies incinerated by a drug cartel. However, the Interdisciplinary Group of Independent Experts (GIEI) commissioned by the Inter-American Commission of Human Rights (CIDH) released an independent investigation earlier this month that refutes the government's claims.
The group had eight demands for the president:
Translation of demands:

Hungry, tired and feeling the abuse of a government that doesn't care for them or the sons that they've lost, expressions of angst, deep resentment and anger were evident. At their meeting, President Peña Nieto told parents he would work with the attorney general to create an investigative unit dedicated to finding people who have disappeared.
Translation: I informed them (the parents) of the various measures, including the creation of a Special Prosecutor for the Search of Missing Persons (4)

At a press conference at the Zocalo square, where parents and supporters have camped out, human rights attorney, Vidulfo Rosales Sierra, who is representing the parents and acts as mediator between the group and officials, told press, "the parents reject the creation of a special prosecution and thus, the failure of the items proposed." Rosales cited that the president's proposed plans were already in motion and don't clearly allow for international oversight on continued human rights violations.
Mario Gonzalez, a parent of one of the missing 43, told the press:
It is necessary to continue to search, to find our 43, we will not give up.

Throughout the late evening, after the press had left and the crowds had thinned out, music groups, poets and supporters stayed behind. They entertained the volunteers, the parents, attempting to lift their spirits if only for a few hours. text: Little Sophie Cruz, 5, broke through a barrier line on Wednesday at a parade for Pope Francis in Washington, D.C., and delivered a powerful message on immigration, hunger, war, dignity and respect for humanity.

After breaking through the barrier, Sophie, dressed in a traditional Oaxacan embroidered dress and two braids adorning her face, was being escorted back by security guards when Pope Francis called her over and blessed her. Sophie handed him her letter and yellow shirt that read, "¡Papá Rescata DAPA!" (Pope, Rescue DAPA!).

DAPA (Deferred Action for Parents of Americans and Lawful Permanent Residents) is one of two Executive Orders signed by President Barack Obama to help undocumented immigrants with a pathway to legalization. The program could be jeopardized with a Republican administration.
A child is escorted back before Pope Francis called for the child to be brought to him, during a parade in Washington, Wednesday, Sept. 23, 2015. (Alex Brandon, AP)
Pope Francis reaches from the popemobile for a child that is brought to him, during a parade in Washington, Wednesday, Sept. 23, 2015. (Alex Brandon/AP)
In her letter, Sophie said she was scared her parents might be deported and that she has a right to be happy. She urged the Pope to care for children who don't have their parents.
Don't forget the children, watch those who suffer because they don't have their parents – because of war, violence, or hunger.
MSN interviewed Sophia and she recited her letter in Spanish:

"Hola me llamo Sophie Cruz, tengo 5 años, soy ciudadana Americana de raíces Mexicanas. Vivo en Los Angeles, California en el corazón de la agricultura. Mis padres son indígenas de Tuxtepec, Oaxaca, Mexico. Papa Francisco, te quiero contar que mi corazón esta muy triste porque tengo miedo que alguien dia que el ICE deporten a mis papas. Yo tengo derecho de vivir con mis papas. Yo tengo derecho de ser feliz. Mi papá, trabaja muy duro en una fabrica galvanizando fieros. Todos los inmigrantes como mi papá, alimentan este país. Por lo tanto, merecen vivir con dignidad. Merecen ser respetados. Merecen una reforma migratoria porque a mi país le conviene y porque se lo han ganado trabajando muy duro en la pizca de naranjas, cebollas, sandia, melones, espinaca, lechuga, y muchos vegetales mas. No te olvides de nosotros los niños, mira aquellos que sufren porque no tienen a sus papás – por la guerra, por la violencia, por el hambre."
Translation:

"Hello, my name is Sophie Cruz, I am 5 years old, I am an American citizen with Mexican roots. I live in Los Angeles, California in the heart of agriculture. My parents are indigenous people of Tuxtepec, Oaxaca, Mexico. Pope Francis, I want to tell you that my heart is very sad because I am afraid that ICE (Immigration Customs Enforcement) will one day, deport my parents. I have a right to live with my parents. I have a right to be happy. My father works very hard in a factory galvanizing metals. All immigrants like my dad, feed this country. Therefore, they deserve to live with dignity. They deserve to be respected. Deserve immigration reform because it benefits my country and because they have earned it working very hard farming oranges, onions, watermelon, cantaloupe, spinach, lettuce and many more vegetables. Don't forget the children, watch those who suffer because they don't have their parents – because of war, violence, or hunger."
A slightly different translation of the letter was recited in English by Sophie to The Guardian.

text: Early Tuesday Sept. 22, 2015, federal and state police clashed with student protestors on their way to the capital city of Chilpancingo in Mexico's state of Guerrero to continue their protests demanding the missing 43 students who disappeared on Sept. 26, 2014 be returned alive.

Driving in 12 buses from Ayotzinapa to Chilpancingo as early as 7:30 a.m. local time, some 200 police blocked access to a tunnel in the city of Tixtla. Parents of the students attempted to negotiate with police, but ultimately, nothing was agreed upon and violence erupted when students threw rocks and Molotov cocktails at police, who responded with tear gas.
Local reports indicate at least 14 people  — police and students — were injured.

The clash comes days before the one-year anniversary of when 43 student-teachers of the Raúl Isidro Burgos Rural Teachers' College, better known as the Ayotzinapa Rural Teachers' College, in Iguala, Guerrero went missing. The students were on their way to Iguala to attend a protest on education reform and political transparency when their buses were stopped, never to be seen again.

Earlier this year, Mexico's then-attorney general, Jesús Murillo Karam, claimed the students were captured, killed and their bodies incinerated by the drug cartel, Guerrero's Unidos. However, a new independent investigation led by the Interdisciplinary Group of Independent Experts (GIEI) commissioned by the Inter-American Commission of Human Rights (CIDH) refutes the claims based on new scientific findings. Mexico's new attorney general, Arely Gómez González has reopened the case.
The day before Tuesday's clashes, several protestors broke into the State Attorney General's office in Chilpancingo and destroyed property, demanding the missing students be returned alive.
On Saturday, mass demonstrations are expected in Mexico City while relatives of the missing students stage a hunger strike at the Zocalo Square.

text: Update (September 21, 2015): Syriza won the September 20 elections with 35,47% of votes, and renewed their coalition with Independent Greeks, who entered parliament with 3,69%. Abstention, at 43,91%, was comparatively massive. The coalition's 155 combined seats allow them a slim margin over the minimum 151 required for absolute majority in parliament.

Greek politicians love to use the term 'sovereign people' (o kyriarchos laos), but the Greek people have arguably lost much of their sovereignty over almost six years of harsh mandated austerity with no end in sight from the debt crisis.

The country is holding another general election Sunday, the second this year, with the electorate largely weary and dispirited, after a dramatic round of bailout negotiations in early summer. A fragmented leftist Syriza is polling neck-and-neck with conservative New Democracy at under 30 percent  each, and several parties are vying for participation in a parliament that seems increasingly irrelevant. Capital controls are still in effect, expected to last for months at least.
Here's a look at how the parties are doing, and the main people representing them.
A Syriza supporter at a rally in Patras, Greece. September 16, 2015 (Menelaos Mich/Demotix)

Syriza (polling at 24.5-31%): Alexis Tsipras' personal charm still holds strong, but the leader of Greece's radical left party is having a challenging time explaining to voters why he capitulated to crushing austerity terms imposed by lenders, after the thunderous 'no' delivered by 62 percent in a referendum he called for. Syriza is campaigning on a promise of social justice and reform-driven survival of austerity within the Eurozone.
A New Democracy supporter at the party's main rally in Athens, September 17, 2015. (Kostis Ntantamis/NurPhoto)

New Democracy (polling at 24-28.5%): Although less vehement than his predecessor, Vangelis Meimarakis is running a mostly negative campaign, focused on convincing voters that his beleaguered conservative party – which lost power to Syriza by administering harsh austerity under populist prime minister Antonis Samaras – can deliver stability, as opposed to Syriza's "left parenthesis".
Children at a Golden Dawn election rally in Athens, Wednesday, September 16, 2015. (Lefteris Pitarakis/AP)

Golden Dawn (polling at 5.4-7%): Under trial for operating as a criminal group, but released from detention and running for parliament, neonazi Golden Dawn politicians are attempting to expand their alarmingly high 'protest vote,' that yielded them third place in the last elections, by exploiting the failure of consecutive governments in defeating austerity to undermine parliamentary democracy, and the refugee crisis to hon their anti-migrant rhetoric.

PASOK (polling at 4.6-8%): A shadow of its' former self, and the first party to dramatically implode after introducing austerity measures (from 43.9 percent in 2009, to 4.7 percent in 2015), Greece's socialist party is trying to convince voters that the days of cynical, corrupt administration are past, with a "return to roots" campaign.

KKE (polling at 4.7-6.5%): Staunchly anti-EU and anti-Syriza, Greece's Communist Party has remained much the same through the decades. The biggest change in party views came when its general secretary voiced a critical view of Russia at a leaders' debate. KKE's stance has gained sympathy after Syriza's capitulation, but it doesn't look to be translating into electoral gains.

Potami (polling at 4.1-5%): A centrist one-man platform spun off from a successful TV interview show,  Stavros Theodorakis' party aims to convince as a committed pro-EU reform, anti-corruption alternative to Syriza, by invoking direct contacts with lending institutions while the latter was desperately negotiating for a viable bailout deal.

description: An extraordinary video of an Austrian man singing a Yiddish song to Syrian refugees offers a moment of hope amid the gloom of the refugee crisis.
text: There's a video I saw on YouTube earlier this week, and I can't get it out of my head.

It begins somewhat abruptly, showing a middle-aged man singing to himself while driving a van, filmed by someone in the passenger seat. Sporting a chin beard, spectacles and a cap, he looks like he could be from another era, save for his t-shirt. He's driving leisurely through an unknown central European town, matching the pace of the pretty song he's singing.

At first I assume he's singing in German, but it doesn't take long for me to realize he's actually singing in Yiddish – a delicate, plaintive lullaby that's vaguely familiar. His gentle tenor voice is perfect for the song. It's a peaceful, charming moment, this man singing quietly to himself.
And then he reaches the chorus.

Raising his finger like a conductor signaling a choir, he lets out a brief "ah!" sound. The camera turns to the back of the van, and it's full of smiling people attempting to sing the simple chorus – a chorus I recognize from my childhood. Some of the people manage to sing it, while others are giggling too hard to keep up with him. A restless girl in the back seat appears to be attempting a handstand, her feet almost touching the van's ceiling.
It's a moment of pure, unadulterated joy. And it sends a chill up my spine.

The driver, Austrian singer Hans Breuer, is transporting a family of Palestinian Syrian refugees from Budapest to Vienna. Some of them are dressed in warm winter clothes, while one woman is adorned with with a headscarf. Hans, whose father was Jewish, volunteered to give the family a ride from a refugee camp to Austria. Once there, they would be able to catch a train to Vienna and beyond. To pass the time, he's singing the Yiddish classic "Ofyn Veg Shteyt a Boym" and teaching them the chorus.

Watching the video for the first time was emotionally overwhelming. My team and I have spent the last six months reporting the horrors Syrian refugees face while attempting to seek sanctuary. For some of us, we've been covering the Syrian civil war since the week it began nearly four-and-a-half years ago – a brief period of hope and optimism that has since been crushed under the weight of barrel bombs, chemical weapons and despair. It had been so long since many of us had witnessed even a semblance of hope for Syrian families – and here it was in front of us, an Austrian Jew serenading a Syrian family as he whisks them to a future full of promise and possibility.

The video is inspirational, to be sure, but it's not just the joy you see on everyone's faces. It's in the song itself, which I distinctly remember from my childhood in Hebrew school. I didn't speak Yiddish growing up, so like most of the other kids in my Hebrew school class, we stuck to singing the simple chorus – just like the Syrians were now doing.

"Ofyn Veg Shteyt a Boym" translates to "On The Road Stands A Tree." It's about a young boy named Itzik dreaming of becoming a bird and flying far away from to a desolate tree. He's trying to convince his mother why he must part from her.

Zog ikh tsu der mamen: "her,
Zolst mir nor nit shtern,
Vel ikh, mame, eyns un tsvey
Bald a foygl vern...

Ikh vel zitsn oyfn boym
Un vel im farvign
Ibern vinter mit a treyst
Mit a sheynem nign.

I say to momma: "Listen, 
 If you don't stand in my way, 
 then, one and two, 
 I'll quickly become a bird...

I'll sit in the tree 
 And lull it 
 during the winter and comfort it 
 With a lovely tune.
His mother is devastated by the thought of being separated from her son, but if he's insistent on leaving for a new home, she wants him to be prepared for a hard winter.

Veynt di mame: – ltsik, kroyn,
Ze, um gotes viln,
Nem zikh mit a shalikl,
Kenst zikh nokh farkiln.

Di kaloshn tu zikh on,
S'geyt a sharfer vinter
Un di kutshme nem oykh mit –
Vey iz mir un vind mir...

– Un dos vinter-laybl nem,
Tu es on, du shovte,
Oyb du vilst nit zayn keyn gast
Tsvishn ale toyte...

And momma cries: – Itzik, my crown, 
 As God would want, 
 take a scarf with you, 
 Lest you catch cold.

"Put on your galoshes, 
 It will be a severe winter. 
 And take your fur hat, too. 
 Woe is me!

"And take your warm underwear, 
 put it on, foolish child, 
 Lest you become a guest
 among the dead...

The boy, honoring his mother's wishes, puts on his scarf, his boots and his warm underwear. But the weight of the clothing is too much for him to fly away, as his mother's love for him is simply too heavy. So rather than tearing apart the family, he decides to stay with her, facing an uncertain future. But at least they'll be together.
Kh'heyb di fligl, s'iz mir shver,

Tsu fil, tsu fil zakhn,
Hot di mame ongeton
Ir feygele, dem shvakhn.

Kuk ikh troyerik mir arayn
In mayn mames oygn,
S'hot ir libshaft nit gelozt
Vern mir a foygl...

Oyfn veg shteyt a boym,
Shteyt her ayngebogen,
Ale feygl funem boym
Zaynen zikh tsefloygn...

I lift my wing, but it's hard... 
 Too much, too many things 
 Has momma put on
 her weak little fledgling.

I look sadly straight forward
 into my momma's eyes,
 Her love did not allow me
 to become a bird...

On the road stands a tree,
 it stands bent and deserted,
 All the birds of that tree
 have flown away.

The video and the lyrics remind me of another family's exodus, 75 years ago. My great-grandfather came to the U.S. from Austria-Hungary at the turn of the last century, but much of his family stayed behind. As Nazi Germany took hold of Austria, his remaining siblings became refugees and were forced to scatter. One of his sisters hoped to join him in America, but he wasn't able to procure enough visas for all of her children. Faced with the choice of splitting up her family so most of them could reach America, or staying together with an uncertain future, they chose the latter. They were among the lucky ones: their patience paid off, and the entire family was able to immigrate to Australia, where their children and children's children still live today.

Seventy-five years ago, it was European Jews fleeing their homes, forced to make near-impossible decisions again and again for the sake of their families. Today, it's Syrians escaping war and oppression, faced with many of the same difficult choices – where to go, how to stay safe, how to remain united as a family in such terrible times.
Despite an uncertain future, at least one Syrian family has managed to stay together.
And now they travel onward, with the help of a kind man and his song.
title: A refugee family, a song and a moment of hope

text: Beautiful insight. Meet the families who spent the night sleeping at Belgrade's railway station, who today are travelling to Serbia's border with Croatia in the hope of gaining entry. By Irish solidarity activist, Caoimhe Butterly.

Slovenia suspended the Schengen agreement, by sending trains back to Croatia, and Serbia suspended train services to Croatia and Slovenia. Bosnia is preparing to host refugees, but its capacity is small.

One Syrian refugee was found dead on the Eurotunnel shuttle on Thursday. He is believed to have died from electrocution after a freight train was stopped shortly after the French platforms due to the presence of a number of migrants on the tracks. When the shuttle was searched, a number of migrants were found on board, with one unconscious and one injured.

Chile's coastal towns began the clean up after an 8.3-magnitude earthquake triggered tsunamis. At least 11 people died during the quake and many homes on Chile's coast were lost. The country's preparedness is lauded for having saved lives.

Greece is holding a general election on Sunday, the second this year, with the electorate weary after a dramatic third austerity round in early summer. Capital controls are still in effect, expected to last for months at least.

text: As Hungary shut down its border crossings, refugees are forced to take alternate routes through Croatia and Slovenia as they try to reach Austria and Germany.
But since the first few hundreds started crossing into Croatia, locals immediately warned them of a long-known problem and terrible reminder of Croatia war in the 90s: land mines.

In the early 1990s, Croatian forces relied heavily on land mines to curtail Serbian army advances. But minefield locations were hastily or poorly documented, leading to frequent injuries even among Croatian security forces.

An estimated total of 1.5 million land mines were laid during the war. Despite repeated efforts at de-mining after the war, Croatia was never able to clear its grounds completely. Mines have kept killing and maiming hundreds of civilians over the years, and the heavy cost of de-mining is still weighing heavily on Croatia's economy. Many lists of minefield locations exist, but none is deemed completely safe.

Most landmines locations are in forests and agricultural land, that refugees are usually forced to use along smuggling routes. Their sense of safety – of being able to walk and travel in the open in Croatia – could make all the difference. One area with some of the highest risk is on the border with Serbia.

Despite mine-clearing procedures being partially in the hands of private contractors, Croatia has several public bodies mapping mine fields, clearing areas and offering assistance for victims. According to one of these official bodies, the Croatian Mine Action Center, the area still at high risk covers about 505 square kilometers. Croatia plans to clear all suspected minefields by 2019. Suspected areas are marked by thousands of little red warning flags.

But one of the most insidious aspects of landmines is that their location is not always fixed. Heavy rains, changes in the ground composition, even slight earthquakes can move them, sometimes significantly, making it harder to keep minefield maps current.
Croatians don't really rely on maps, but share updated information on Facebook.

But information in Croatian or even English doesn't necessarily reach the largest number of refugees. So volunteers started crowdsourcing translations – part of a much wider translation effort in all the EU to help refugees access accurate information.

As a country that is still recovering from a terribly bloody war that most of Europe seems to have forgotten, Croatia feels a great sense of responsibility towards refugees arriving via Turkey and Greece.

As the risk of encouraging the use of inaccurate maps is almost worse than having no maps at all, the Croatian government's recommendation in simple: stay on the roads. It's the best way to avoid minefields, well documented or otherwise.

The 5-day protest begins 18.30 everyday in front of the main gate of the Diet Building in Tokyo.

India is facing its worst dengue fever outbreak in five years. Over 1,7oo cases were recorded in New Delhi. A wave of public sympathy following the suicide of a couple, after their 7-year-old son was allegedly denied treatment forced the government to act.

UN officials condemned the 'virtual silence' on the escalating impact of the conflict on civilians. The country's government-in-exile is returning to Aden, as loyalist forces are mounting an offensive on Marib.

Authorities confirmed 12 people died from floods caused by heavy rains in Hildale, Utah, bordering Colorado City, Arizona Tuesday. Two vehicles were caught in the flood killing women and children returning from a local park. The local community is home to a polygamous sect of The Fundamentalist Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-Day Saints (FLDS Church). Hildale Mayor Philip Barlow and member of the church said, "We're greatly humbled by this, but we realize that this is an act of God, and this is something we can't control." Utah Governor Gary Herbert offered the town of Hildale full resources in which 600 first responders and 25 National Guard members assisted in rescue efforts.

Four people were killed by police in Nepal's Rupandehi, including a 4-year-old boy, at a protest against a new constitution being voted on this week, over whether the country will be restored as a Hindu nation. Some 40 people have died in clashes in recent weeks. (AP photo)

The poll released September 15 says 43 percent are worried that war will break out between the countries. Over the weekend, Colombia accused Venezuela of violating airspace with "warplanes," though Venezuela denies the charge, a formal complaint will be filed.

On the eve of Mexico's Independence Day, relatives of the missing 43 student-teachers of Ayotzinapa held actions in their home state of Guerrero. The national festivities known as "El Grito de Independencia" "The Cry of Independence" were adapted to "The Cry of Indignation" by protesters to continue to raise awareness on disappearances. The students went missing on September 26, 2014 and while the government blamed local drug cartels, new independent reports suggest otherwise. On the one-year anniversary, relatives of the students will be holding a hunger strike in Mexico City in front of the National Palace at the Zocalo Square.

Mexico's President Enrique Peña Nieto took to Twitter on Tuesday to announce that eight of the tourists accidentally killed by Egyptian special forces were Mexican nationals. Another UN staff member has been accused of sexual assault in the Central African Republic. There are now a total of 63 allegations against UN staffers and peacekeepers.

text: After a year, the Ferguson Commission, an independent body appointed by Missouri Gov. Jay Nixon, released its final report.

Overall, the report highlights what many in Ferguson know, but the report also calls out what needs to change. Titled "Forward through Ferguson: A path toward racial equity," the report was written for the whole community, not just politicians and leaders.

The commission was appointed in November 2014, three months after the August death of Michael Brown, Jr. Brown's death ignited riots and demonstrations that overtook the nation and led us to question whether police in shootings such as Brown's were racially motived. In a larger view, the events in the months following Brown's death started a national discussion on race and civil rights.

It is a report about racial issues in St. Louis suburb of Ferguson, but also nationally. The report's authors say they hope this is the start of a path toward a better St. Louis, but that started with an uncomfortable acknowledgement of the larger problem.
We have not moved beyond race. St. Louis does not have a proud history on this topic, and we are still suffering the consequences of decisions made by our predecessors.
Here's an overview of what you'll find in the report, is fully embedded below:
The Ferguson Commission report looked at issues, not a timeline of events.

The commission highlighted repeatedly they were trying to lay down a framework. Instead of telling a narrative of the events that led to Michael Brown's death, they sought to find the underlying issues.
Ferguson residents didn't trust the police, or the courts.
In reviewing use of force in Ferguson, the commission found  repeated issues led to distrust between the community and police:
The regular use of force has led many citizens to view the police as an occupying force in their neighborhoods, damaging community trust, and making community safety even more difficult.

Fixing that is a big part of the report, and the commission outlines use-of-force procedures that need to be changed like assigning different bodies to investigate incidents, adding civilian review committees, and long-term issues, like training police officers better in cultural conduct.
"To help decrease biased policing, officers need to be trained in cultural responsiveness and trained to recognize the impact of historical trauma," says the report.
In protests, the commission lists specific recommendations for responding and respecting the rights of demonstrators and press covering demonstrations.
The underlying issues: Courts and sentencing reform, schooling, health and welfare.
The report, like the damning Justice Department report released earlier, picks on Ferguson's courts, as well as the Ferguson Police Department.
But unlike the Justice Department, it also focuses on how schools and larger issues contribute to circumstances that make for an unequal community.

The report spends seven pages on the problems with schooling in Ferguson and nearby communities. It focuses on hungry kids, and unfair discipline for younger children that lead to too much time out of the classroom.
"Some schools in the St. Louis region discipline students as young as pre-kindergarten through 3rd grade with out-of-school suspensions and expulsions," says the report.
There's also a specific recommendation to expand Medicare in Missouri to 138 percent of the federal poverty level (annual income of $32,913).
There are 189 policy recommendations in the Ferguson Commission report, ranging from Ferguson Police changes to Missouri-wide issues like payday loans.

That specificity is common throughout the report. The commission looked at the statistics, and drew them down into exactly what needed to change in Ferguson, the St. Louis area and Missouri, perhaps even the country.
The authors of the report admit this — they sought expert opinions from across the country, "appreciating that the challenges we examined were not unique to our region."
This is not the end of their work.

The commission still has one last thing to do before it ends its work — outline the next steps for the community of Ferguson, which includes a new oversight body to ensure many of the recommendations happen.
The organization could be new or made of existing community partners. Listed are Justice For All, Youth at the Center, and Opportunity to Thrive as potential partners.

text: In Italy, one of the countries embroiled in a heated debate about the fate of thousands of migrants and refugees entering Europe daily, people took off their shoes and started marching.

The march was called "La marcia delle donne e degli uomini scalzi" ("The march of barefoot men and women") and dozens of cities participated on Sept. 11 including Turin, Naples, and Rome. In Venice's Lido, dozens of celebrities and high-profile Italians marched, barefoot, to the Venice Film Festival.
(Translation: Part of the #piediscalzi march in the spotlight of the Venice Film Festival: The barefoot on stage)
More than 4,500 people RSVPed to the Lido march on Facebook, many posting photos of their feet during the march.

Organizers, including many non-profits, wrote a manifesto on the march, asking for safe corridors for refugees, hospitality for all arrivals, closures of detention camps and the creation of a "system of asylum in Europe surpassing the Dublin regulation":

We are on the side of barefoot men.
Of those who need to put their body in danger in order to hope of live or survive.
It is difficult to understand it if you've never had to experience it.
But the absolute migration requires exactly that: completely undress of their own identity in order to hope to find another. Leave everything, putting your own body and that of your children into a boat, a truck, a tunnel and hope that it arrive intact beyond, in an unknown that rejects you, but that you need.
These are the barefoot men of  the twenty-first century and we are with them.

More than 432,761 people have crossed the Mediterranean Sea so far this year, in hopes of a better life in Europe, according to the International Organization for Migration. Italy's Prime Minister Matteo Renzi published an open letter on migration on Friday, saying the European Union is at a crossroads and needs to surpass the Dublin Treaty, which details asylum rules drafted in the 1990s. The EU is meeting Sept. 14 to discuss the refugee crisis.

text: "WHERE Y'ALL FROM?" the woman behind me asked no one in particular. She was wearing a Cat-In-The-Hat cap decorated red, white and blue; how she wasn't sweating to death in this heat was completely beyond me.
"I came in all the way from Kansas," one woman chimed in. "And my sister just drove up from Florida."
"We're from Palm Springs," an older couple said, over to my left.
"I just came in from West Virginia," a young man added.
"And how about you?" she asked me.
"Oh, I'm from around here," I said.
Around here. As in DC.
She stared back and blinked, as if waiting for me to explain myself.
"Actually, I grew up in Florida and live up towards Baltimore now."

Her smile returned, and the conversation quickly moved on to the unseasonably hot weather. Whatever concerns she might've had of me being from inside the Beltway had for now, at least, been deflected.

THOUGH the Stop The Iran Deal rally was ostensibly organized by The Tea Party Patriots, the people who showed up to the rally clearly came to the issue from a number of backgrounds. There was a large contingent of Ted Cruz supporters, many of them sporting campaign paraphernalia. #TeamTrump seemed to have less representation, despite the fact that The Donald was scheduled to speak shortly. I probably saw 10 people wearing a Cruz accessory for every one person I saw sporting one of Trump's "Make America Great Again" navy/golf/baseball/whatever caps.

Pro-Israel activists were pretty much everywhere, including evangelicals and zionist groups, though an assembly of ultra-orthodox Jewish men held their own gathering across the street from the US Capitol, perhaps hoping to avoid mixing with women at the rally. One such woman stood just behind me, her three little kids in tow. She was wearing a tallis, a traditional Jewish prayer shawl.
"I'm told I should be careful about not dropping it," she told one her fellow activists.
"You're not Jewish?" the woman replied, mildly perplexed.
"No, but I thought wearing it would be appropriate, all considering."

The conversation was interrupted when another women came by with a large stack of protest signs reading STOP THE IRAN NUCLEAR DEAL, the word STOP stylized as a red stop sign. "Take 'em and pass them out," she encouraged, and the crowd around me happily complied. "We've got bigger ones if you want one," she added, gesturing to a poster custom-made to criticize Sen. Barbara Boxer (D-CA).

Mass-printed protest signs dominated the crowd, though there was no shortage of homespun posters. "A NUCLEAR IRAN MEANS A 2ND HOLOCAUST" read one in grave dark stenciled letters. Another addressed GOP leaders John Boehner and Mitch McConnell; "REPUGNANT TRAITORS," I thought the sign read. Looking at it again, I discovered the word "REPUGNANT" was actually "REPUBNICANT," which I assumed was an agglutination of the words REPUGNANT, REPUBLICAN and CAN'T. Or perhaps REPUBLICAN LUBRICANT, though that seems less likely, given present company.

Some of the protesters made a point at taking a dig at #BlackLivesMatter, often using a play on the phrase "American Lives Matter," sometimes affixed with the word "Too" at the end. Another sign – apparently the obverse of the REPUBNICANT sign – sported the phrase #JewishLivesMatter: Ask God.  I took a pass and decided not to take up the challenge, working under the assumption that sourcing might prove difficult.

BY 1PM, the crowd had grown from just a couple hundred people to maybe 1,000 or more. The crowd was overwhelming white, though a few African American and Latino faces could be seen, scattered among the flags and protest signs. It skewed toward Baby Boomers, though there was no shortage of Millennials spread amongst the crowd. Meanwhile, after a John Cougar Mellencamp medley, the PA system briefly switched to Cheap Trick Live At Budokan, but then thought better of it after getting halfway through "Ain't That A Shame." (Here's the rest of it in case you're feeling cheated.)

Just as I was beginning to debate with myself whether the musicians in question would've approved or disapproved of their cameos at the rally, an emcee took the stage and announced that there would be over 50 speakers over the afternoon. Apart from a handful of keynotes, everyone would be limited to just two minutes. "Politicians stopping at two minutes – yeah, right!" exclaimed the gentleman next to me, my neighbors laughing in agreement.

The first speakers seemed to pass by quickly – not necessarily because they were forgettable, though some of them were – but largely because much of the crowd's attention was focused on what was going on behind stage. A throng of security men, aides and photographers huddled together like penguins in a snow storm, momentum moving them forward ever so slowly. At the center of this mass of dark suits and cameras, a bright flash of orange caught my attention. Perfectly coiffed, orange hair.
Trump had arrived.

Of course, everyone had a job to do, so the speakers kept speaking and some of the audience kept cheering and booing at appropriate moments. But in my little corner of the crowd, all eyes were on The Donald – or more accurately, they were on that flash of orange hair that bopped along the center of the scrum, occasionally coming up for air. For some reason I imagined the TV character Alf, adrift and drowning at sea, his ruddy hair occasionally making it above the waterline.

Trump had at least four other people ahead of Himself at the lectern, so he passed the time the way he does best, holding court and taking questions from fawning fans and press alike. Yet one speaker wouldn't allow the billionaire to suck all the air out of the rally.

Sen. Ted Cruz took the stage and the crowd went wild; he definitely had home-team advantage. Sporting a pressed white shirt and striped blue tie, Cruz wasted no time making his argument against the Iran deal. His prior experience as a champion debater shone through as he went point by point, lambasting the specifics of the deal, as well as the people that are supporting it. His remarks were brief, but confident. It didn't matter that Trump was scheduled to speak next – Cruz would be no one's opening act.

Now it was Trump's turn to take the stage. Just as he began to speak, several campaign toadies volunteers spread along the barrier between the candidate and the crowd, raising Trump for President posters above their heads. Perhaps it made for better television, but it didn't make for better stagecraft, as the signs now blocked the view of everyone in the front rows. While parts of the crowd chanted "USA! USA!" as he spoke, the front rows cried out, "Take down your signs! Take down your signs!"

The sign-wavers didn't get the message, so the crowd up front did the natural thing – standing on the tips of their toes and holding their camera phones as high as possible, creating a chain reaction where everyone else behind them was forced to do the same. Even the orange luminescence that is Trump's hair failed him now, obscured by a tidal wave of iPhones, sweaty hands and irritated protesters. Any plans I had for taking pictures of him were now tossed asunder, as I too held up my camera as high as I could, snapping every which way in a pathetic attempt to capture him for posterity or something. The result was several dozen photos of clouds, trees, PA systems, out-of-focus security guards, and an occasional flash of Trump's head cropped down the middle.
Close.
Not much better.

"I could help you with that," a very tall young man said just to my right. As my luck would have it, he was actually talking to the very nice lady from California, who was struggling to hold up her Galaxy S6. She gladly handed him the camera phone; his lanky arms rose ever upward, somehow getting a pretty good photo of The Donald that would elude me.
"Here you go," he said to her once he was done with the phone.
"Thank you – that was so nice of you!" she exclaimed. "You're so sweet – your father certainly raised you right."
"Yes ma'am," he replied, "both of them did."
"Yes, I see," she smiled awkwardly, before returning her attention back to the blur of orange in front of us while there was still time to do so.

text: Roszke, Hungary, September 8: Just a few hours before European Commission president Juncker's State of the European Union address, refugees are smuggled through fields and forests in an attempt to evade the Hungarian police close to the Serbian border. In Roszke, hundreds have just fled from a migrant camp after being diverted from trains bound to Austria. Many migrants fear that if they are forced to officially register and have their fingerprints taken, this will stop them being able to move freely out of Hungary and further into Europe. Most will be reassured about this only if and when they are able to reach Austria and then Germany. Photographer Dan Kitwood crossed at Roszke with a group of them.
(All Photos: Dan Kitwood/Getty)

text: Reported.ly's Asteris Masouras spent a week in Lesvos, the third largest Greek island, which is receiving the largest share of the refugee exodus from Turkey. Over 160,000 people, mostly from Syria and Afghanistan, have crossed over to Greece so far in 2015, with 33,000 of them having crossed the narrow 10km strait to reach Lesvos just in August so far. The island is overwhelmed by the numbers, but local social initiatives, with the support of volunteers and contributors from around the world, make up for the crippling deficiencies of the formal aid system to respond to people in need.

Refugees reaching Lesvos are eventually channeled to two camps outside the city of Mytilene. One of them, Kara Tepe, is a converted traffic park, chicken-fenced and split down the middle by the access road, housing primarily Syrians. The other refugee camp, Moria, is an EU-funded formal detention center, fenced with razor wire and guard posts, housing other nationalities. Refugees at both locations are overflowing capacity, languishing in deplorable conditions, made marginally bearable by the efforts of volunteers and a handful of NGOs.

Activists from the Village of All Together arrive in Kara Tepe in a staggered convoy, then unpack the materials needed to cook and serve food to hundreds of refugees. As the sun beats down mercilessly on the asphalt, Syrian refugees mill around, waiting for lunch to be served. The activists politely struggle to keep them from crowding at the table. Upon my remarking on the large number of people queuing for food, Konstantinos Polychronopoulos breaks out a big, warm grin.
"This is nothing; we fed 2,000 people yesterday."

Seeing the cameras, a trio of youths approach and strike up conversation. Nahid, a young, bespectacled and soft spoken man offers to translate for the others. "What do you think of Mr. President Bashar al-Assad?" he says, signaling in a tone that one of his friends expects to hear praise. The friend is quick to laugh, appreciative of Greek women, and supportive of the Syrian president. He points to a muscled youth nearby, tattooed with daggers "This guy almost killed me," he says. "Just kidding." The dagger-tattooed youth is a shabiha, a member of the regime's armed thugs, as Nahid confirms later. The last member of the trio is a Kurd from Kobane. He offers no details on his story, other than to repeatedly point out that a united Kurdistan is within grasp as a result of the current conflict.

Nahid – whose name we've changed to protect him from further persecution – tells me that he was a journalist in the northeastern Syrian city of Hasakah, which he fled after threats by ISIS over his critical Facebook posts. He tried to find work in Dubai, but he was told to fight for the rebels if he wanted a visa. Nahid complains about the unemployment and low wages in Turkey. He continues to post criticism on Facebook under his real name. All three want to seek asylum in Germany, without knowing exactly why. Smiling, Nahid poses for a photo, but I tell him that I won't publish it so as not to endanger him. After the others join the queue, Nahid confides that he's no regime supporter: "I am a moderate; I blame all sides for the war."

Kara Tepe offers sparse amenities to the hundreds of refugees arriving every day. Segregated shower stalls and toilets were installed by the International Rescue Committee and Medecins Sans Frontiers, but British expat Eric Kempson, who periodically comes over to help clean the toilets, criticized hygiene conditions at the camp. In another visit a month later, he conducted a spot inspection of the toilets – now in dreadful condition – and commended the International Rescue Committee for keeping the part of the camp clean and orderly.

Today, the left side of the camp looks marginally cleaner than the right side. The only protection from the sun can be found at a small amphitheater, alternately used by police officers conducting registration – the entire reason refugees congregate here – and a Medecins Du Monde (MDM) contingent, performing routine medical screening. MDM also operates two more field units: one at the Moria camp and the other at the port of Mytilene. Refugees mill around the amphitheater, enjoying a respite from the sun while waiting for their checkup; a kid tethers to my phone's data plan to check on his Facebook page.

Giorgos Bakas, the social worker who heads the MDM presence at the camp, is constantly busy, but agrees to talk to me at his office in Moria. We make a short stop at the Mytilene port, where the MDM mobile unit providing checkups and information is parked next to a registration booth. Dozens are crowding along a fenced, muddy strip, hoping to get their papers and catch a ship to Piraeus on the Greek mainland. Three children's drawings depicting homes are taped up on the fence.

Moria is an oddity, a detention center where thousands are crowding to get in. Hosting non-Syrian refugees, for whom fast-track processing is not available, it has taken a more permanent aspect of a shanty town ringing the perimeter of a Gitmo-like facility, with razor wire fences and guard towers surrounding the containers housing the refugees inside. Unlike Kara Tepe, Moria has no amenities for those biding their time outside the camp. All manner of canopies  – from triangular field tents, to hiking domes, to silos and makeshift lean-tos – are pitched everywhere on the shoulder of the road. Dust rises with every movement, and waste water pools on the ground, only to seep downhill. Security issues also loom outside, as only a handful of police officers work at the facility and the road is ill-lit at night. The pent-up frustration of thousands waiting for an indeterminate time for their papers in deplorable conditions, with no amenities and care to keep them occupied, often results in scuffles.

As we arrive, a long lunch queue snakes down the road. Medecins Du Monde and other organizations operate from a row of air-conditioned containers atop the camp. The entrance is ringed by tents, and their occupants plead to make their way in whenever the chain-link fence swings open. MDM's Giorgos Bakas tells me that his organization is operating at its limit, striving to at least provide the minimum of essential medical care and allow refugees to retain their dignity. But the island cannot handle over 1,500 new arrivals per day.  Better reception facilities are needed to manage the inflow and avert tensions, he says, and the EU has to respond appropriately.

Sebastian Reich comes by for a visit, surprised that he was allowed in, and we make our way down to a dilapidated building outside the facility, where dozens of people find shade under the awnings that he and the team from The Village Of All Together erected. Their next project, to begin the following morning, is to dig a proper drainage system, as the pools of waste water are a serious health risk. They're also thinking of setting up a PA system, so people waiting to be called for their papers don't miss their turn.

Solidarity activists and aid workers operate in overlapping parts of the refugee ecosystem, sometimes collaborating, often coexisting in mutual tolerance and occasional mistrust. Intergovernmental organizations and NGOs are constantly criticized by volunteers for their absence, or discrepancies between their communications and infrastructure work. For instance, Medecins du Monde also has a booth set up outside Moria, but activists say they've never seen it used.

Back in Mytilene, Sebastian tells me that he never expected to be participating in such a social solidarity project, or to see so many people live in such dreadful conditions. Winter is coming, arrivals will continue, and the waiting will be harsh for refugees – especially once the volunteers, tourists and media are gone.

Not long after my departure from the camps, refugee arrivals in Lesvos surpassed 33,000 people, overwhelming all capacity at the camps and the port. Α 47-year-old Somali woman died of a stroke in Moria on August 31, reportedly due to the harsh living conditions, and another bitten by a snake was taken to hospital. On September 4, clashes erupted in Mytilene when hundreds of Afghans tried to board a ship to Piraeus, and the Coast Guard fired stun grenades to push them back. On September 7, hundreds marched in downtown Mytilene, demanding to be allowed to leave. A marathon operation to fast-track 15,000 applications for travel permits, on September 8, temporarily cleared the bottleneck in Mytilene, and defused tensions.
