text: Fifty Turkish warplanes bombed Kurdistan Workers' Party (PKK) targets in Northern Iraq Tuesday. Prime Minister Davutoglu vowed to destroy the group after 16 soldiers were killed in an ambush in the Yüksekova district of the southeastern Hakkari province. Another attack on a bus with a roadside bomb blamed on the PKK killed 10 police officers in Igdir. Turkish nationalists attacked over 120 provincial offices of the pro-Kurdish HDP party.
The crackdown on members of the press who wish to work in Kurdish areas is fully on. After two reporters from Vice News were released last week, their Iraqi colleague is still being detained.
Turkish journalist Fredericke Geerdink was arrested on Sunday while working with Kurdish members of HDP,  who were detained too.

Rowan County clerk Kim Davis, who was jailed for failing to follow a federal court order by continuing a "no marriage licences" policy, has taken her own case by requesting an exemption to Kentucky Governor Steve Beshear's "mandate" that marriage licenses be issued.
Thousands of arrivals are recorded daily across the European refugee trail. Over 350,000 are reported to have travelled to Europe in 2015 by IOM; UNHCR expects the total figure to rise to 400,000.

In Lesvos, thousands of refugees demanding passage to the mainland were attacked with teargas by Coast Guard officers. Two 17-year-olds who threw petrol bombs at refugee tents on the night of September 6 were arrested. In Kos, Amnesty witnessed 15-25 thugs with bats attack refugees, shouting "go back to your countries".

The Hungarian defense minister resigned, reportedly over delays in the construction of the border fence. Hundreds of refugees at the outdoor Roszke holding center broke through police lines and started a march to Budapest. Refugee numbers at the capital's Keleti train station, the scene of dramatic standoffs and departures in recent days, have been ebbing and flowing, depending on the availability of buses and trains to Austria.

On Greece's border with Macedonia, violence has been reported by security forces on both sides against thronging refugees. On Monday night, thousands broke through despite beatings. Only volunteer organizations are reported to be responding at the Eidomeni border.
Over 10,000 arriving refugees in Munich were greeted warmly by residents and the mayor.

Dortmund, Munich and Berlin all witnessed anti-refugees neo-nazi protests over the weekend, kept in check by German police. But in calling for other EU countries to take their fair share of refugees, vice-chancellor announced on Monday that Germany could take as many as 500,000 a year.
UK PM David Cameron announced on Sunday that Great Britain will receive 20,000 Syrian refugees – about the number of refugees a British ship in Mediterranean helps rescuing every month.

It looks like Australia may reconsider its steely stance on refugees: New South Wales premier Mike Baird said they could take more than 10,000. Meanwhile, tens of thousands held vigils across Australia to show solidarity with refugees.  Many fear a prioritising of Christian refugees.
In Zuwara, Libya, the updated number of bodies recovered from the tragic shipwreck of last Thursday  is now 183.
Around 1,500 police vehicles took part in the funeral cortege Monday of 52-year-old police officer Charles Gliniewicz, who was shot dead while pursuing suspects in Fox Lake, Illinois last week.

Guatemala: elections to find a successor to former president Perez Molina are underway. Stripped of his immunity, Molina faces prosecution on corruption charges. In Sunday's first round vote, Jimmy Morales, a television comedian who campaigned under the slogan "Not corrupt, not a thief," won almost 24 percent of the vote, only a few thousand votes aways from second place finishers.

Another opposition member was assassinated in Burundi's capital. Patrice Gahungu, the spokesman of minority party UPD was killed after midnight in Bujumbura. Gunfire and explosions were again reported in the capital.

In the UK, after Prime Minister David Cameron admitted sanctioning a drone strike that killed two British Islamic State members, Defence Secretary Michael Fallon said that further such action could not be ruled out.
In Burma, Aung San Suu Kyi kicked off the electoral campaign in the country's first free general elections saying a transitional period will necessarily follow.

text: Refugees that have spent several days sleeping on the floor of the Keleti station in central Budapest, Hungary, were finally able to board buses taking them to Austria early Saturday morning.

On September 4, a little before midnight local time, Austrian Chancellor Werner Faymann announced on Facebook that after meeting with Hungarian Prime Minister Victor Orban and German Chancellor Angela Merkel, Austria and Germany would received refugees without interference or issues.

Earlier on Friday, trains with refugees heading towards Vienna were stopped by Hungarian police and forced off. More than 1,000 people then decided to walk the 130+ miles towards freedom, #MarchOfHope began to trend. Those walking included women, children, men, elderly and people with disabilities. In the wee hours of the morning on Saturday, buses picked them up along the highway to safely take them to the Austrian border. The Austrian Red Cross was ready to receive them.

The local police unsuccessfully tried to stop them outside Budapest city limits, after they crossed the famous Elisabeth Bridge. Further up along the way, Hungarian citizens are offering them food and help, encouraging them to go on. One of the men leading the march is carrying an EU flag.

Dozens of victims of the dictatorship of Hissene Habre in Chad told horrifying stories at a press conference on Thursday, in Dakar, Senegal, where Habre trial – strongly endorsed by the African Union – is about to resume. Very soon, they will have to testify against Habre in court.

Maldonado took the oath of the Presidency just a few months after becoming the country's Vice President in May when former VP Roxana Baldetti resigned over corruption charges. text: Violent clashes between police and refugees broke out on two Greek islands on Thursday evening and Friday morning as tensions flared amid a worsening crisis. A standoff continues at Bicske train station in Hungary, where hundreds of men, women and children are being held by police in train carriages in stifling heat.

Dramatic scenes erupted on Lesvos island where some 33,000 refugees arrived in August alone. Running battles around the port area spilled onto the streets of Mytilene as police fired stun grenades into a crowd of refugees trying to board a ferry to Pireaus. The port area is closed off Friday afternoon, and refugees are "trying to find a place to rest," it reported.

Some 25,000 refugees are believed to be on Lesvos, many waiting weeks for registration to be processed before they can move to mainland Greece and onward to Europe. Most have traveled here to rebuild their lives having fled conflict and persecution in Syria, Pakistan and Afghanistan.
Video geo-located to the Port of Mitilini on the east of the island shows scores of people sleeping rough Thursday night.
This video filmed Thursday also at the port gives a sense of the number of people camped out there.
Some people collapsed in dire conditions Thursday as they waited to be registered.

Migrants collapse as they wait to be registered by police in the port of Mytilene, on the Greek Aegean island of Lesbos, on September 3, 2015. More than 230,000 refugees and migrants have arrived in Greece by sea this year, a huge rise from 17,500 in the same period in 2014, deputy shipping minister Nikos Zois said on September 3.  (ANGELOS TZORTZINIS/AFP/Getty Images)
On Thursday evening, activists on the Greek island Kos reported that police charged at a crowd of refugees, hitting them and firing tear gas.

In a separate incident, "thugs", thought by some to be affiliated to the right-wing Golden Dawn party, attacked refugees and activists, threatening those providing much needed assistance to Greece's stretched services.
One person working with Amnesty International was threatened:

An Amnesty International report on Thursday's violence and the "deplorable conditions" on Kos called on European leaders meeting Friday to agree "immediate action to end the prolonged suffering of thousands of refugees."

Researchers found children as young as a week old among the crowds forced to wait for days in baking heat to be registered by the local authorities, and interviewed unaccompanied minors being detained in deplorable conditions alongside adults.

Tensions are also escalating in Hungary where borders were closed Thursday (our story here). A standoff of over 24 hours at Bicske train station is ongoing with police who tried to forcibly redirect hundreds of women, children and men aboard a train bound for Austria to "registration camps".

A "feverish" atmosphere was described Friday at Budapest's Keleti train station, where thousands of refugees – mainly Syrian and Afghani – are trapped with international rail travel suspended. They have been protesting for three days as conditions deteriorate.
Desperate to make their journey onward to Germany, some have decided to walk to Austria.
title: Refugee crisis escalates as violence breaks out

text: This week's police-related news coverage in the US helps shed light on the current climate of police and civilian tensions, and the way those stories are told. Here's an update on a few stories we've been following:

On Wednesday, Judge Barry Williams denied a motion to dismiss the charges of the six officers involved in the fatal shooting of Freddie Gray, 25, but granted that each be tried separately. The judge stated "it is not in the interest of justice" to hold the trials together. In addition, he also denied the motion to have State Attorney Marilyn Mosby recused from the case based on her remarks at a press conference earlier this year. Judge Williams said Mosby's comment's "do not rise to the level where the defendants' rights to a fair trial have been violated." Freddie Gray suffered a severe spinal cord injury while in custody of the Baltimore police department when he was arrested on April 12, 2015. He died less than a week later. Our previous story:

A video of Bexar County police shooting Gilbert Flores while his hands were up has surfaced. Last Friday, deputies in Bexar County, TX were responding to a domestic violence call when they approached Flores, who was in his driveway. The video, shot on a cell phone by a neighbor, shows Flores with his hands up when he was shot. Controversy has surrounded the video as the sheriff's office took to Facebook and Twitter to discredit local news station KSAT12 for airing the video, calling it "unethical and sad." The office also took the unusual step of encouraging social media users to telephone the station and complain about the video. KSAT12 for its part released their reasoning, emphasizing the importance of transparency and accountability in the county. A second video has also been reported, though it is not yet available to the public. Bexar County Sheriff Susan Pamerleau said Flores appears to be holding a knife and the video has been sent to Texas Department of Public Safety's crime lab. The two officers have been placed on paid administrative leave.

Police continue to search for suspects in Lake County, IL after a 30-year veteran of the Fox Lake Sheriff's Department was fatally shot. Early Monday morning at approximately 8am local time, Lt. Charles Joseph Gliniewicz was on foot-pursuit of three suspects and was found shot and stripped of his gun shortly after he called in the suspicious activity. Local police, SWAT, FBI and US Marshals went on the search for two white males and one African-American male suspected of the assault. Schools and libraries were closed down and a no-fly zone was declared in the area. Community members also held a vigil in his honor Tuesday evening.

Despite dashcam footage showing Ernesto Rodriguez, 31, being beaten and arrested by Knoxville, TN police in July of last year, he is now facing resisting arrest and assault charges. Rodriguez, who is undocumented and suffered from severe injuries including having his face fractured, has filed a civil rights violation suit against the City of Knoxville and has turned himself in for the charges. A lawyer for the Fraternal Order of Police has said that police thought Rodriguez was going to be deported rather than "clogging up" the justice system. Police also claim he was not injured by the beating but by the moment "his face smacked against the pavement." Rodriguez is set to appear in court on September 10.

Three San Bernardino deputies have been charged with "assault by a police officer" for beating Francis Pusok in April of this year. Pusok led deputies on a horse pursuit in a mountain region that was caught on camera and broadcast live on local news. In an interview with NBC4 he said he thought he was being beaten to death.

Murder charges for ex-police chief Richard Combs were dropped when he pleaded guilty for misconduct for the 2011 fatal shooting of African-American Bernard Bailey. The former police chief of the small town of Eutawville in South Carolina and Bailey appeared in court for a traffic ticket when they began to argue. As the defense for Combs tells it, Bailey got in his car and suspecting he was going to be run over, Combs shot at the vehicle. Two previous trials ended with hung juries. Combs was sentenced to one-year home probation.

text: Reported.ly's Asteris Masouras spent a week in Lesvos, the third largest Greek island, which is receiving the largest share of the refugee exodus from Turkey. Over 160,000 people, mostly from Syria and Afghanistan, have crossed over to Greece so far in 2015, with 33,000 of them having crossed the narrow 10km strait to reach Lesvos just in August so far. The island is overwhelmed by the numbers, but local social initiatives, with the support of volunteers and contributors from around the world, make up for the crippling deficiencies of the formal aid system to respond to people in need.

Sebastian Reich is a tall, unassuming 33-year-old German actor with the Badisches Staats Theater in Karlsruhe. He became involved with an independent activist movement helping refugees in Lesvos after a friend, who spent weeks on the island, was haunted by the harsh conditions facing the multitudes of refugees arriving here. He staged a play to inform theatergoers about the issue, managing to crowdfund 4,000 euros, and arrived in Lesvos, seeking for practical ways to help them. He began by cutting their hair, and continued by putting up canopies for shade, and repairing drainage at the Moria refugee camp.

Sebastian is one of a multitude of activists, including islanders, Greeks from other parts of the country, tourists and aid workers, now volunteer with ad-hoc refugee assistance networks. Several such networks exist in Lesvos, succeeding in responding to the crisis where traditional aid organizations have failed.

Located on a now-defunct campus that once served special needs children, the Village of All Together is a self-sustained, all-volunteer refugee camp. The village has been administered since December 2012 by social activists with no access to state or EU funds, after local authorities offered the use of the site.

A group of local volunteers – mostly women – runs the camp, handling supply logistics and organizing field visits to other locations where their services and resources are most needed. Boxes of donated aid fill a large storehouse. Packed foodstuffs, piles of clothes, toys for children – they all have to be sorted, stored safely and distributed to the refugee camps, while more donations arrive every day.

The volunteers start the day planning their field visits and other activities under the welcome shade of the trees, as smiling refugees file out from their tents to greet them. There's a shared languid serenity in this place, but also purpose: volunteers and refugees form loading-unloading brigades as cars file in and more people arrive, offering help every hour.

A jeep bearing activists from a local social kitchen arrives, loading up an impressive amount of goods. Konstantinos Polychronopoulos and his colleagues manage small miracles, cooking on site for hundreds at the camps outside Mytilene every day. They started out by cooking for crisis-stricken people of all nationalities in Athens, but the current refugee crisis has focused their efforts on the islands this summer. On the previous day, they cooked 2,000 portions for refugees at the Kara Tepe camp.

On the way to Kara Tepe, we drop a young Austrian volunteer at the airport. After several days spent working with fellow Village of All Together activists, the prospect of going back home to Vienna, where "the streets are so clean you can eat off them," feels surreal to him. There's a refugee camp outside Vienna as well, where he says conditions are deficient, so maybe he'll find a way to help there. He's now part of a larger network of people supporting refugees in Lesvos from around the world.

Over the next several days, I too will discover that sense of the surreal that many volunteers feel after departing the island. Lesvos empowers and haunts you with a sense of purpose, of strong solidarity, and a measure of desperation, like having pulled back a curtain to reveal another world.
title: Lesvos Diary: The Village of All Together

description: Refugees packed on trains, numbered and segregated for "registration" camps – Europe's political xenophobia is being spearheaded by Hungary's crusading Prime Minister who wants to save "Christian identity." Chaotic scenes broke out Thursday at Hungary's Bicske rail station as Hungarian police stopped a train packed with refugees, separated them from European passengers and sought to forcibly redirect them to refugee ...
text: Chaotic scenes broke out Thursday at Hungary's Bicske rail station as Hungarian police stopped a train packed with refugees, separated them from European passengers and sought to forcibly redirect them to refugee camps.
Shouting "No camp! No camp!" one man desperately huddled with his wife and child on the rail tracks, which lead to Austria and then Germany, as police tried to move them from the station.

Those seeking passage to Germany, where some 800,000 asylum applications will be accepted in 2015, refused to be corralled into buses bound for so-called "registration" camps. They eventually returned onto train carriages in stifling midday heat, though some were later removed to an unknown location by bus.
Trains packed with refugees, mostly Syrian, were stopped by police at Bicske and outside Gyor on Thursday (Google Earth)

Earlier Thursday morning, authorities reopened Budapest's Keleti station but said that international rail travel was cancelled "due to security reasons." Several journalists boarded the train, curious to know where it would go.

Following the distressing scenes in Bicske, police denied those reporters access to the platform as the train was boarded again. British editors James Mates and Lindsey Hilsum were there to record events.
Further down the line, on another train "in the middle of nowhere" near the Hungarian city of Gyor, police evacuated another train of refugees in an attempt to move them to camps.

As Hungary's riot police played enforcer in scenes reminiscent of twentieth century ethnic-cleansing, their nationalist Prime Minister, Viktor Orban, gave an astonishing address in Brussels, where he met European politicians:

Those arriving have been raised in another religion, and represent a radically different culture [to Europe]. Most of them are not Christians, but Muslims. This is an important question, because Europe and European identity is rooted in Christianity.

"Please don't come," said Orban, who oversaw the construction of a fence along Hungary's entire border with Serbia. He said said that asylum seekers are legally required to be registered in Hungary before leaving for another country.

Until Tuesday, Hungary's border with Austria remained open with thousands of people moving from Budapest to Munich, where most wish to travel. The suspension of travel from Budapest has exacerbated already poor conditions for thousands of refugees waiting at Keleti station to travel onward, sparking protests each day.

Were Orban sincere in his sudden legal requirements, registration facilities would be provided where refugees gravitate – transport hubs. The UNHCR's representative in Hungary, Babar Baloch, has called on authorities to provide "fair access to asylum" and a "proper reception" for refugees.

Orban's position appears to have the tacit support, if not encouragement, of European Council President, Donald Tusk of Poland, who said Thursday that Europe must "seriously address the containment of the wave of migration by strengthening borders."

He called for the "fair distribution of at least 100,000 refugees" – a paltry number given that 33,000 new arrivals landed on the Greek island of Lesvos in August alone, that thousands are crossing eastern European borders daily, and that Germany alone expects 800,000 to arrive in 2015. European Commission President Jean Claude Junker is expected to table a distribution of 160,000 refugees, according to The Guardian, but even that fails to grasp the scale of the crisis.

European foreign ministers meet Friday to try and find common ground. Many experts in humanitarian affairs argue strongly for legal instruments to allow the greater movement of people. Noting the absurdity that refugees spend thousands of dollars risking their lives to reach Europe when a flight from Cairo costs less than $100, the UN High Commissioner for Refugees spoke to CNN's Hala Gorani.
In June, Jan Egeland of the Norwegian Refugee Council spoke to reported.ly about the migration crisis and Europe's failure of political will to address it:
European leaders [must] sit down as they did when the banks were threatened. If they take the survival of banks as importantly as they did, why not the survival of people?
title: Chaos and desperation as Hungary closes its borders

text: There's a photo you should look at, but I don't want to start another fight.

There's been too much bickering as of late whenever someone posts a graphic photo online that also happens to be newsworthy. We could spend the entire day navel-gazing over what's "appropriate" and what's not. Maybe we could even kick it up a notch and start a Twitter war until we all end up blocking each other.
So rather than argue about yet another photo, let me just tell you about one.
It's a photo of a little boy, and he drowned this week. His name was Aylan Kurdi, and he was just three years old.

In the photo, Aylan's body has washed up on the shore of a Turkish beach. His boat capsized while trying to reach Greece, killing him, his five-year-old brother and nearly a dozen others. He and his family came all the way from Syria, fleeing the unending horrors of war.

Aylan is face down in the water, his arms limp by his side. He's splayed along the shoreline, submerged in no more than an inch of water. In a better world, he probably would have loved this very spot: a beautiful beach where he could chase seagulls and dodge the outermost ripples of ebbing waves, giggling each time he escapes one.

He's had a haircut recently – and if he's anything like my own son, he would've been proud to show it off and tell everyone what a big boy he was. His hair is brown, but exactly how light or dark is hard to tell, as it's slicked back with sea water.

He's wearing a red t-shirt and blue shorts. A bit of his tummy is exposed – the perfect target for his five-year-old brother while attempting to defeat him in a tickle fight. Again, in a better world.
Aylan's hands are very small. Probably too small to catch a ball easily, but that probably never stopped him from trying.

He's wearing tiny shoes – the kind of shoes that look adorable even when a little boy isn't wearing them, because you can immediately picture how a kid would look in them. The treads on the soles of his shoes still look relatively intact. Maybe someone was kind enough to give him a fresh pair as he awaited the next phase of his journey from Turkey to Greece.
Like I said, I won't force you to look at him. But I truly wish you would. It will break your heart; it will make you angry. And that is exactly how you should feel after seeing it. Seeing him.

Maybe just once we could set aside these endless debates on what's "appropriate" to post online. All the arguments and Twitter fights in the world won't change the fact that a little boy named Aylan is dead, along with thousands of other refugees, just because he and his family wanted to start a new life, away from war and suffering – and the world couldn't get its act together to figure out how to help them.
That's not a debate; that's a catastrophe.
title: This is not a debate about graphic photos. This is a catastrophe.

text: Referenced over and over again in the search for answers in Bangkok's Erawan shrine bombing is a Facebook page with more than 570,000 followers.

For more than two years, the Facebook group known as CSI LA has focused on solving crimes in Thailand. The group, managed by David Anantasin, has grown rapidly, and its work is cited by Thai and English media. Prior to the bombing in Bangkok, for example, the group exposed a hit-and-run driver who killed a cyclist.

"We just have this discussion group," Anantasin, 38, says somewhat bashfully. "I just pose a question. But then my page has a lot of followers so we have people from different occupations. The police do not have this kind of network."
Since the bombing in mid-August, CSI LA has received a new spotlight and gained thousands of fans in just a few weeks.

One of their first posts on the bombing debated the amount of explosives used and how much damage it could do. The community discusses everything from how the bomb could fit in a backpack to the blast radius of five kilos of TNT.
This, Anantasin says, is what his page is about. It's an experiment – one he hopes produces more "American-style" consumption of media in Thailand.
"If you have 1,000 brains working together, you have a super computer, and you have the people on the ground who can provide you information."

Thai police haven't always been enthusiastic about CSI LA. At one point last year, a police spokesman said his office was considering taking legal action against Anantasin and the page. But it's become an important source for news organizations around the world. Most posts on the page have hundreds comments, while images posted there are often found on other Thai and international media within a few days of posting. One recent post of a potential suspect was leaked to Anantasin by police on Friday of last week and ended up being referenced by the Associated Press the following Monday after it had made the rounds in Thai media.

Anantasin says he has several sources in the police department, in addition to official communication with Thai Royal Police, but he also gets amateur videos and photos. He also posts news articles he thinks are noteworthy.

Anantasin is far from a mercurial sleuth who lives behind his computer. He prefers to be out and about, managing CSI LA from his cell phone. He's not even entirely fond of being called a sleuth. He says he doesn't want to be Sherlock Holmes and "find the guy." He wants to change the way people respond to media in Thailand and to help the police at the same time. It is the police's job to catch the bad guy; it's just that CSI LA is better at processing information than anyone there right now.
"I want the police to accept help from the outside," he says, whether it's him or the community at large.

In some cases, that's worked. Anantasin said in the case of a sex worker who was brutally murdered in Bangkok's Red Light District, the police officially called him after seeing his posts and asked for help.

Asked if he thinks the police in Thailand are incompetent, he says that incompetent is a "harsh word," but with international eyes on the police chief should have more media savvy than to hold and impromptu press conference under a giant sign that says "suckers."
David Anantasin, who runs CSI LA. (Photo: Courtesy)

When Anantasin talks about CSI LA, whether he's calling it his passion or his hobby, his voice speeds up. He is a fast talker to begin with, but there is a literal twinkle in his eye when he speaks about it.
He is fully aware of this.
"I talk faster when I get excited," he apologizes.
The page began as a few posts when Anantasin was frustrated with portrayals of Thai protesters in 2013. He was sick of the conflicting and biased news. "I could not stand it," he says.

His personal posts did so well his friends joked that he was something of a CSI out of Los Angeles, but that he shouldn't use his name with his posts, just in case. Anantasin took the comments to heart (though he doesn't watch or really like crime dramas) and created CSI LA.

The first big story Anantasin and company worked on was the Koh Tao case in 2014, when two British backpackers were murdered. The case was riddled with issues — from forensics to policework. A verdict is expected for the two Burmese migrants accused of the crime this fall.

His family jewelry business taught him to be on the lookout for potential thieves. His degree from UCLA in international economics, focused on east Asian studies was about his love of information and politics. His new master's degree in predictive analytics from Northwestern makes every piece of information, every story he reads, a different data point.
"For me at this point it's not about fame or anything," he says. "Even if I have 100,000 likes, I don't care. You have to find the pattern."
That search for the pattern, the clues, is a core part of Anantasin. "In the jewelry business, my job is to make sure people don't steal," he says. "I have to think like a thief all the time."
His family, from his wife to his six siblings in Thailand, have no idea what he is doing.
"They don't even know, they don't care. They don't know what I do."
Anantasin is also very involved in the Rotary of Monterey Park, which has a large Thai-American membership. The Rotary has shown him that doing what you love, and what gives back, matters.

"What can I do, you want to sit down and cry? Or you want to help the police catch the bad guy?" he asks. "I follow my passion so it doesn't look like a job for me. When you love what you do, you don't feel tired."

text: Hundreds of people gathered at Lebanon's Ministry of the Environment in Beirut Tuesday evening as a deadline – imposed by #YouStink organisers – for officials to resign lapsed. A few dozens activists staged a sit-in at the 7th floor corridor of the building demanding the resignation of the minister. Electricity was cut off, riot police entered the building and evicted reporters, phones inside the building were confiscated and protesters were forcibly removed, many reporting beatings, some hospitalized or taken away in handcuffs. Check out our story and the Global Voices special coverage.

#EUMigrants: MOAS/MSF ships rescued more than 1,000 people from three boats on Wednesday, as 9 different operations were in progress, while 11 refugees drowned when a dinghy capsized off the coast of Turkey, en route to Kos.

Hundreds of migrants and refugees spent the night at a sit-in outside Budapest's Keleti train station, after authorities suspended train traffic and cleared the station Tuesday. On Wednesday morning, Hungarian police kettled hundreds still protesting.

Read the eyewitness accounts of people across Yemen targeted by airstrikes and rocket attacks since March. We made this StoryMap to raise individual voices above the numbers and show the true effect of a hidden conflict.
Evidence was drawn from researchers in Yemen, including journalist Iona Craig, writing for our sister publication, The Intercept.

A 28-year-old was arrested after a pepper spray attack on a refugee shelter in Massow, Germany, that hospitalized 14 people, including 5 children. Kurdish and Belgian activists rallied in Brussels to protest criminalization of migration. Meanwhile, should Hungary block the flux of refugees, Croatia would become a new transit zone: PM Zoran Milanović said they're ready, but there is no plan.
In a further blow to press freedom in Azerbaijan, investigative journalist Khadija Ismailova was sentenced to seven and half years in prison by a court in Baku Tuesday.

The trial of Congolese warlord Bosco 'The Terminator' Ntaganda began today at the International Criminal Court in the Hague. He is charged with war crimes committed by the Patriotic Forces for the Liberation of Congo in 2002-03, specifically with conscripting child soldiers.
Tuesday was a heavy day of police issues in the U.S. adding to the current climate of police and civilian tensions:

Ernesto Rodriguez, 31 (pictured) was badly beaten in July 2014 by the Tennessee police who arrested him in Knoxville. Rodriguez, who is undocumented, now faces resisting arrest and assault charges. He has filed a civil rights violation suit against the City of Knoxville and turned himself in for the charges. He will appear in court on September 10.

Three San Bernardino deputies were charged with "assault by a police officer" for beating Francis Pusok in April 2015. Pusok led deputies on a horse pursuit in a mountain region that was caught on camera and broadcast live on local news. In an interview with NBC4, he said he thought he was being beaten to death.

A video of a Texas sheriff shooting Gilbert Flores while his hands were up has surfaced. Last Friday deputies responded to a domestic violence call when they approached Flores who was in his driveway. The video, shot on a cell phone by a neighbor shows Flores with his hands up when he was shot. Controversy has surrounded the video as Bexar County Sheriff's took to Facebook and Twitter to discredit local news station, KSAT12 for showing the video calling it "unethical and sad." The station released their reasoning as to why transparency is important.

Murder charges for ex-police chief Richard Combs were dropped when he pleaded guilty for misconduct for the 2011 fatal shooting of African-American Bernard Bailey. The former police chief of the small town of Eutawville in South Carolina and Bailey appeared in court for a traffic ticket when they began to argue. As the defense for Combs tells it, Bailey got in his car and suspecting he was going to be run over, Combs shot the vehicle. Two previous trials ended with hung juries. Combs was sentenced to one-year home probation.

There was a manhunt in Lake County, in Chicago, Illinois after a 30-year veteran of the Fox Lake Sheriff's department was fatally shot. Early in the morning at approximately 8am local time, Lt. Charles Joseph Gliniewicz was in foot-pursuit of three suspects and was found shot and striped of his gun shortly after he called in the suspicious activity. Local police, SWAT, FBI and U.S. Marshalls were on the manhunt for two white males and one African-American male suspected of the assault. Schools and libraries were closed down and a no-fly zone was declared in the area.
Thailand officials announced that the fingerprints of the main suspect they arrested on Tuesday do match those found on bomb-making material.

text: Al Shabaab mounted a car bomb and gunfire attack on an African Union base in Somalia, killing dozens of soldiers. The attack was launched on the first anniversary of Al Shabaab emir Ahmed Abdi Godane's killing by a U.S. drone strike. AMISOM refuted claims that the base had been captured.

#EUmigrants: A day after Austrian police stopped trains with refugees on the border, Hungary shut down all traffic at Budapest's main train station, and ordered refugees and migrants gathering at Keleti station to leave. Hundreds waiting for trains out of the country protested outside the station.
Some 20,000 people marched in Vienna on Monday in a show of solidarity with refugees, and activists showed up at train stations to assist 3,650 people arriving from Hungary.

Over one hundred people were rescued from a dinghy at night by the MSF/MOAS Dignity I ship, a day after it rescued another 119 people. Some 10,000 people have been rescued from Meditteranean waters so far in the first year of the joint operation.

Frontex said that 23,000 refugees and migrants had arrived in Greece last week. The number of arrivals all along the route from Turkey to Germany through the Balkans has been burgeoning in recent days.

Meanwhile, as campaigns to welcome refugees began in Germany and Sweden, 10,000 Icelanders offered to resettle Syrian refugees, after an author launched a Facebook campaign in response to the government's plans to accept only 50.

In Kiev, more than 100 people, including dozens of National Guardsmen, are still in hospital after being injured on Monday when a device exploded during a nationalist protest in front of the Ukrainian parliament. A few are in critical condition and one Guardsman died.
Injuries were reported in Jenin, West Bank, when clashes broke out following an Israeli raid to arrest a Hamas leader in the city.
Thailand officials announced on Tuesday that the main suspect in the Erewan bombing was arrested. Rumors that he was arrested in Cambodia were later denied.

In Kentucky, a county clerk is facing a tough decision after she continuously denied marriage licenses to gay couples. Rowan County Clerk Kim Davis is now being sued by one couple and the U.S. Supreme Court has denied a case, seeking to say she has the right to deny the licenses on the basis of religion.

Two Vice media employees are being held in Turkey since last Thursday for terrorism charges, which Vice says are baseless. Jake Hanrahan and Philip Pendlebury were detained while reporting on PKK and tensions in Turkey. Their driver was initially detained but later released.

Another chemical explosion happened in eastern China.  The blast hit the eastern city of Dongying at nearly midnight local time Monday, three weeks after the massive Tianjin blasts. This is the second blast in one week in Shandong province. Little information exists about the latest blast. One person was killed, according to the Shanghaiist. (Weibo)
The UN released satellite photos that confirm the Temple of Bel in Palmyra has been destroyed. ISIS has been on a rampage, destroying multiple sites in the ancient city.

Guatemala's president, Otto Perez Molina appeared before press for the first time since he was formally accused of corruption. The country has been embroiled in protests demanding Molina's resignation. Another is planned for Tuesday. Despite this, he says he will not resign, denies the charges and wishes for the upcoming September 6 elections to go as planned.

Venezuela's President Nicolas Maduro made claims that the government of Colombia has been plotting his assassination. While on a trip to Vietnam, the president said, "I have proof that will show that from Bogota, they are forming a campaign to kill me." His remarks also come while 34 Western Hemisphere nations began talks at the Organization of American States in Washington to discuss the various border closures between Venezuela and Colombia.

Tropical Storm Erika barreled through the Caribbean over the weekend causing severe damage. At least 20 people died and 31 are reported missing in the small island of Dominica. Mudslides levelled a town in Haiti and more 200,000 people were left without power in Puerto Rico. The storm caused some $16m in damage to Puerto Rico's crops. The storm also impacted the Dominican Republic and parts of Cuba.
